commentBody: Thanks Henry, there's four things I'd never heard of before this puzzle!

LOL@44D

Thank you.

So fun! 44D gave me a huge smile. Could live without MIRAMAX but on the other hand it really is ok for puzzles to have ugly words.

Can‚Äôt wait for more‚Äîthank you Henry!

This tasty puzzle left me hungry for more. The puzzle highlighted one of my favorite foods ‚Äî MAPOTOFU.  When I was learning how to cook during my college years, it was one of the first things I learned how to cook.  After graduating, I was looking for a summer job and walked into a Chinese restaurant here in suburban Ardmore where my fianc√©e and I had enjoyed several meals and asked for a job.  To my surprise, the owners interviewed me.  On the strength of my ability to describe how to cook MAPOTOFU (and perhaps also because I agreed to tutor their 8 year old son in English) they offered me a job as the third cook.  I spent a great summer learning the restaurant trade and the secrets of Chinese cooking.  Fast forward 20 years, and after years of living in Philly I moved back to Ardmore, and went back to eat at the restaurant, where the son was now the head chef, and he and I are friends to this day.

Ahhhh.  Empty calories and dial up, could anything else better remind me of the 90‚Äôs? 

This puzzle is a treat.  Thanksü•∞
A COSMO, pickles and MAPOTOFU, then some MINITWIX‚Ä¶ makes a meal.

Awesome debut, and you can see all the work that went into making it work so well, so that even if you didn't know something, like John Cho, you could get it on the crosses with a little more work than usual. (With Star Trek on my mind, I got Jean-Luc Picard and Jean-Luc Goddard confused and thought it was another Trek clue. Indeed, Alphaville is a Marxist, New Wave, noir version of Star Trek: think of the Grand Omega Minus, where activists are sent out into the galaxies to foment rebellions. But I do go on).

It's interesting that this puzzle dates from 2021, when AG Barr was still a fresh in our minds, and when DOGE didn't yet bear the tarnished fingerprints of Elon Musk and his evil sidekicks.  Now it took a few moments to summon Barr's chipmunk visage and vacant, defiant stare. Empty calories. 

Yup. Going to make me a Mai Tai, have some mocha torte, maybe some milk toffee, too. This puzzle made me hungry!

Meat Tornado. Good one.
Great clue for LITANY but mainly thanks for reminding me of ‚ÄúLitany‚Äù by Billy Collins‚Ä¶ https://www.lyrikline.org/en/poems/litany-7640 There is just no way that you are the pine-scented air.
Really fun! Henry you nailed 44D.
That was fun. Loved 44D and 56A. Great debut puzzle, Henry!

SETUP
DIAL UP
INK UP
PONY UP

What‚Äôs up with that?

I‚Äôll join the MAPO TOFU fan appreciation club! One of my favourite dishes and one that I like to make from time to time. I can‚Äôt say any of the other food items appealed, although my two favourite summer drinks were there - COSMO and BEER. Happy DAIS at the BARR!

I was really out at sea with this one, had no idea what many of the entries were all about. Maybe I'm getting old?  What is moose tracks? Mapo tofu? is this something that is popular? mini twix? meat tornado? Really? These words are from another planet.  I'm sure a lot of effort went into this but it was just too strange for me.

Haha.  Brought to mind‚Ä¶

When asked for the abbreviation for Montana, I say MT as ‚Äúin big empty state‚Äù!
Am I alone in always being curious about Park and ReC‚Äôs Mear Tornado? Who else would try it?

Someone please save me from the rock I've been living under!

Maybe it's because tofu isn't my food preference, but I shamefully admit to never having heard of the dish.

Also, never having watched "Parks and Recreation," MEAT TORNADO could just as well have been MEga TsuNAmi were it not for the crosses.

The one that bruised my ego, though, was thinking the Mona Lisa might have been painted on WOOl. Was WOOD taught in the one Art History class I skipped to go to the beach instead? Quite possibly. 

One thing I do know very well is DIAL-UP.  Tired of the constant wait and wasted time, I once told my modem, "You do your thing while I go take my shower (*and* have breakfast, *and*...) I stuck with this M.O.  every morning thereafter.

By the way, that was my favorite clue. Thank you for that and for a great debut, Mr. Lin-David. Congratulations!
Just here to add my appreciation for 44D. That‚Äôs just how I would have spelled the clue! Great debut.

"Junk food puns are soda-lightful."
"Got any more of them?"
"That's nacho concern."

("I donut know why I ask.")
Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Mr. Lin-David! Nicely done!

Is it just me, or did this puzzle feel much harder than a Tuesday? While the theme was consistent with a Tuesday difficulty, I was nearly 3 minutes over my average. Some clues felt verging on the Wednesday part of the spectrum, and some stretching into Thursday category, which doesn't not feel right for a Tuesday. It's a clever theme, but what is a TOOLROOM? Didn't everybody, when they first read the clue, thought TOOLBOX?
Toolroom?!? Cmon, do better.

An odd Tuesday combination of Monday-easy fills and pop entertainment that made me (rightly, sometimes) mistrust the easy clues but accept that I would have to get them to figure out the TV and movie names. While I have heard of "Parks and Recreation," I have never seen it; I had long since forgotten that John Cho was "Lt. Sulu"; AdRien Brody gave me something to go on for the Hammer home, but the R nixed the known tool sheds and toolboxes. So I asked my husband, (Master of Arcana) for help, and he remembered Nevil Shute's novel "Trustee from the TOOLROOM."

I have never constructed a crossword puzzle, but I know how difficult it must be, especially for a debut, so my congratulations to you, Henry Lin-David.  You really got me going!

What a strange puzzle this was for me. I knew none of the themed entries, which made things quite difficult for a Tuesday. Trivia-based themes are not my favorite. In the end I managed to fill the grid without outside help but I can't say I particularly enjoyed it. It didn't inspire me to post anything interesting, either.
What a tasty puzzle! I did this just about 5 minutes faster than my average Tuesday. I'm going to reward myself with my favorite food group, EMPTY CALORIES üòú

This doesn‚Äôt relate to today‚Äôs puzzle, but rather to something I noticed in yesterday‚Äôs comments. Mid-day yesterday, a somewhat regular, but infrequent commenter, who goes by a handle that matches that of a pediatric psychiatrist on the mid-Maine coast, posted a benign comment complimenting the Monday puzzle. A very regular commenter, who happens to be a retired marine biologist also from Maine, made a brief response which caused more than one of us readers to expel coffee through our noses. I left a post expressing my appreciation of this subtitle, but admittedly perhaps a bit crude, post by the marine bivalve mollusk Naval officer. Before long, I noticed that the entire thread was gone. Once again, it seems that even an innocent, benign post can be completely erased by a comment of someone, or some bivalve, downstream‚Ä¶good to know‚Ä¶.
Northeast corner felt a little clunky. I didn't enjoy the trivia but could solve them with the crosses. Not entirely enjoyable but nonetheless well constructed .

Tuesday was more difficult at first for me, and then fell neatly and quickly into place. LINUX popped up like magic but DOGE, MEATTORNADO and a couple others took longer.

There was a time when I would have called my daughter from across time zones to tell her BTS was mentioned.  Friends, I lived through a level of fanaticism with her that I would have thought was a gross exaggeration if I saw it on television or read it in a book! Every cell in her body was BTS coded ü§£. She talked about ‚Äúthe boys‚Äù all day, everyday. She spent her part time job money on exorbitant concert tickets. She ~camped out in a tent~ outside said concerts, along with a throng of other fanatics. She knew every detail about every group member. It was exhausting as a mom, but bittersweet. 

Now, she‚Äôs a grown lady living 3,700 miles away from me with a career, a partner, bills and a whole life that I‚Äôm about 5% aware of. *Sigh*

Anyway, if that LITANY of complaints about those fan years doesn‚Äôt make me drink a morning COSMO üçπüç∏üç∑ then I think I‚Äôm safe üòä.

Have a great day, everyone!

Thanks for the shout out to Jean-LUC Godard on the anniversary of the day of his birth. Godard's is one of the few birthdays on my Google calendar. He changed film editing forever with BREATHLESS. This bit of self-indulgence contains a nod or two to Godard. https://vietnamgardens.hotlikethedesert.com/

I was quite perplexed by the SE corner until I realized my guess of Meat Tsunami was supposed to be Meat Tornado. No, I have never seen Parks and Rec, and neither would I want to see either of those disasters on my dinner plate!
Nice debut, Henry.  I loved your clue for DIAL UP.  Really captures the sound perfectly.

Loved the DIAL UP clue. 
Totally said aloud. Nice morning chuckle.
Husband raised a brow, but it‚Äôs too early to explain.

A Sulu *and* a Jean LUC?
Nice!

Thank you Henry!

Add me to the list of people who found this unusually difficult for a Tuesday. Maybe it's small-town Vermont talking, but never heard of MAPOTOFU (although I would zip right by any menu item that includes tofu, so that could also explain it), and I found MOOSETRACKS to be similarly obscure,, even though once I got it it sounded like something that originated here at Ben & Jerry's. Twix? Never had one myself, but also never tried unsuccessfully to buy one, unlike George Costanza: https://youtu.be/hUs9KaOTcOU?si=QPFt4pTQXLGWMmDq

Well, I see at least one example already, but I can't help but wonder if this one was unusually difficult for some of the other boomers in this community. Just quite a few unknowns or things that I was at least never going to connect to the clues. Had to google some stuff and somehow managed to work it all out. And... never really caught on to the theme until after I was done and went back and reviewed and pondered. Not a complaint - that's all on me.

Might post some puzzle finds in replies later. We'll see. 

...

Relieved to see this was a tough Tuesday for more than just me. A great theme once I worked it out, chewy but doable. 
Completely unaware of the foods in today‚Äôs offering, bar TWIX, though haven‚Äôt seen mini ones. Because I espied a food theme I had Parma before PANSY, but got there in the end. EMPTY CALORIES indeed.
Very clever for a Tuesday! But allow me one quibble. MAPO TOFU -- new to me but sounds yummy -- may well fit in with MT calories, but hardly EMPTY calories.  I mean, come on. TOFU?

(second try)

That is one poppin‚Äô good theme, with every theme answer and the reveal appearing in the NYT puzzle for the first time in its more than 80 years. And all those answers had verve.

That set the tone for the whole puzzle, which, to me, had a fresh feel from top to bottom.

Part of it was just from the images that came popping into my mind: baseball cap, Adrien Brody‚Äôs face, mapo tofu on a plate, pickles in a jar, choppy waters, soccer official holding up a card, an elephant flapping its ears.

But the best imagining was working to hear that dialup sound. Hah! What a ridiculously silly fantastic clue!

Then there was the amazing TIL that the Mona Lisa was painted on wood, along with brushes with beauty (WREAK, LITANY, PONY UP). Not to mention the lovely fauna (MOOSE, MAHI, ELEPHANT, and the father of a mule).

One happy ping after another, this puzzle was a mood elevator from top to bottom. All on a maiden Times puzzle, and oh yes, I‚Äôm eager to see more. Congratulations on your debut, Henry, and thank you for an exhilarating outing!

Why is it regrettable that elephants can't fly?

Don't get the joke.
Please describe how mapo tofu is empty of calories.

If our constructor hadn‚Äôt written such a clear set of steps *down*,

this would have been a recipe for disaster.



Instead, happy to say I managed a full grid with zero energy.
Found this one oddly unsatisfying to solve, perhaps because I haven't heard of many of the food items. Did enjoy the dial up clue though
Now I could go for a nice slice of MOCHA Torte! https://dairyfarmersofcanada.ca/en/canadian-goodness/recipes/mocha-buttercream-torte
Actually one of my quickest Tuesdays. It was one of those where there was plenty I didn't know, but I knew enough where it didn't matter. It felt satisfying
The constructor notes are just delightful. What a fun, supportive family!

Seems from the comments that this one skewed a bit younger than a lot of recent puzzles, but I hope the constructor doesn‚Äôt take the more persnickety comments to heart. This was fresh, funny, and surprising - a nearly perfect Tuesday.
Has anyone in this discussion ever read/heard/said the word "toolroom"?

Flying elephants, the sound of a dial-up modem, Parks and Recreation, silly food theme. Utterly delightful Tuesday solve from start to finish. The constructor‚Äôs comments were charming too.

It got me thinking. Do I say EM-tee or EMP-tee? I think I say EMP-tee. Didn‚Äôt detract from my enjoyment, however. 

Off to jury duty.

I noticed the M Ts fairly quickly, but still found this difficult for a Tuesday, but no problem, I still had fun.  It‚Äôs also fun when the constructor is so excited, and hopefully that means we will be seeing more from Henry.

A fine nutrition packed debut.  Many thanks.  

I have a TOOLROOM, but it is on wheels.

To quote Ron Swanson is Parks & Rec:

"You had me at Meat Tornado."
A reminder to do the Bonus Puzzle. It's a Beatles theme this month, so put a vinyl LP on your turntable and enjoy! (I just listened inside my head.)
An elephant never regrets!

So much to love about this puzzle! ‚ÄúBeep beep beHAW‚Äù etc. was hilariously accurate and oddly nostalgic in a non-wistful kind of way. I‚Äôve never heard of Moosetracks, but now I want some, very badly. Who knew Mule‚Äôs dad was such a jerk? And any reference to Parks and Rec is going to make me smile, so thanks for that.

Oh, any for anyone complaining about a Tool Room, they exist. Mine used to be called a garage.
Great debut puzzle, thanks Henry!
The sound effect at 44D made my day.

I lost my original writeup and have no energy to reproduce it -- so let's just say that I hate TOFU, would never mix peanut butter with fudge, and hadn't heard of any of these MT concoctions.  But I liked the wordplay of the puzzle and its relative Tuesday crunchiness.  And now a word about the TOOL ROOM:

Last week we had to guess whether it was a TOOL KIT, TOOL BOX, or TOOL SET.  Today the tools have their own entire ROOM.  It looks like tools are taking over the entire world -- or at least the NYTXW.

I figured there would be push back for MAPO TOFU as soon as I filled it in. I love the stuff, but I had never had it until I lived in Sichuan. (My eye is not naturally drawn to the vegetarian section of the menu.) We were having lunch at the Green Ram Temple, in Chengdu, and the restaurant there is vegetarian, because it's Taoist. My traveling companion suggested the dish, knowing I like spicy food, and I was hooked. MAPO translates to "pockmarked granny," alluding to the old lady who invented it.
Question: What does a completed crossword shown in yellow mean versus shown in blue? Thanks for your help.
TOOL ROOM?

Having eaten my share of Moosetracks, the "empty calories" stung a little until I understood the MT. (I have also eaten Michigan Pothole ice cream, which is just as good.) And at first glance, I thought Hammer's home was Great Britain, but that has only one "m."  This was a really fun puzzle.
I'm feeling a little peckish, just going to pop over to the FOOD ROOM and make myself a snack.
With all of the UPs (SET UP, INK UP, PONY UP, DIAL-UP), I started to wonder if it was part of the theme!

I worked in a machine shop when I was in HS, and there was, indeed, a TOOL ROOM in the facility, where there were all sorts of large tools, such as Bridgeport milling machines. They would build specialized jigs and tools that were used in the production facilities of the small factory. 

There were small tools such as hammers in there, too, although storing hammers was not the primary purpose of the TOOL ROOM. 

The answer does not bother me. Somebody, somewhere has a TOOL ROOM that is exactly as the clue describes.
I was excited to know "MAPOTOFU" immediately because I LOVE mapo tofu. It's such a comfort dish! If you haven't tried it, I'd encourage you to give it a whirl!

MAPUTOFU was a Natick for me, but only because I had CuP instead of CAP in 11A. That gave me UDOL_O for 12D, which could be a name for all I knew. I ran the alphabet, which didn't help, until I finally saw my mistake and ADOLFO was obvious.

It took a little longer than my average Tues time, but I got there.  I thought the "MT calories" theme was cute, but the foods used were a little obscure...  to me, anyways.
I don't think pileup is a good clue for litany. A litany really is a recitation or list.

44D might be my all-time favorite clue ever! 

@Marshall Walthew, thank you for that lovely story. It made me happy.
Imagine getting that dial-up modem clue through in your debut puzzle, what a coup! Great stuff!
this one was pretty easy except for TAMPS / PANSY.  I suspect I will never see TAMPS outside of a crossword.

I was unfamiliar with all four of the theme entries which made this puzzle a kind of a chore.

It seems to me MINITWIX has been invented for this puzzle as a stand-in for ‚ÄúTwix Minis.‚Äù  Is that kosher?

Egad! After eight Reveal Words I still needed reveal puzzle for the remaining wrong square. Believe it or not, my U in MEATTuRNADO. So many other new things in this puzzle (MAPOTOFU, MINITWIX, ADRIEN Brody, and of course JOHN CHO, etc.) that it seemed that could very well be right.
This puzzle was an absolute delight!!!! I laughed out loud a couple of times! MEATTORNADO 4EVER PAWNEE HEADS RISE UP
I have a tool room. It is made out of red sheet metal and it is almost exactly the size of a bread box. Smallest room in the house and that's saying something.

I used to have a TOOLROOM but my BARCART was getting too cramped so converted them to a TOOLcart and a BARroom. My own little EDEN!! 

Fun puzzle and theme. My only problem is that my brain continually insists on spelling it DiaS instead of DAIS. Easily with only a small hit to my EGO.

I just had to comment on this one--I loved it, and like others have said already, the sound effect clue for 44D was so much fun! Really brought back memories of the old days of the internet and dialing up with a 1200 baud modem! üòÑ

Does anyone else remember the really old acoustic coupling ones that required you to put your telephone handset onto the modem? I think the first time I saw one was in the movie War Games. ü§î
Delightful jovial lovely no notes
44D made me laugh üòÑ
Absolutely adored this puzzle.  The Parks and Rec clue really brought a smile to my face (if you haven't watched it yet, do yourself a favor and do so)!  A new personal best for a Tuesday!
Well, this was an absolute blast.

I‚Äôll post this‚Ä¶*

On the great vigil of Easter, the Great Litany is sung. Part of it includes petitions:
‚ÄúFrom x and y,:‚Äù
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äúdeliver us  O Lord.‚Äù

This was all done in Latin, so the choir repeated throughout the Litany:
‚ÄúLibera nos, Domine‚Äù (Deliver us, O Lord).

Halfway through the Great Litany my mother  (then pre-teen) whispered in her mother‚Äôs ear:
‚ÄúWhy is the choir so mean!‚Äù

     What do you mean?

 ‚ÄúWell, they keep saying ‚ÄòLeave her on a stormy day!‚Äô‚Äù

*it will be suppressed

James Agee. A Death in the Family. Prologue. Starting up a jalopy. If you enjoyed the clue for 44D, do yourself a favor. Get that book and start reading
(letters on a page)
and turn AGEE from crosswordese into
a brilliant writer.


It‚Äôs too bad I waste my finger pokes on these posts,
since
NONE
of them ever get through.

The clue for 44D is wrong:  It should be 

beep beep beeHAW beeHAW beeeEEEeeep SHRHRHRHRH

The last beep was too short.

I wish the editors would get on this kind of stuff, as it is ruining the crossword for everyone.

Oh, how I do remember dial-up!. Got into being online and ended up getting a second phone line just to keep downloads or uploads from constantly being ruined when someone picked up a phone elsewhere in the house. Was extremely grateful when cable internet became available and I could get faster speeds and get rid of the extra phone line.

As for the puzzle, it was straightforward and fun. Not familiar with mapo tofu, but the crosses were fair and got everything finished in short order.

Nice debut, Henry, and thanks!
The clue for DIALUP had me chuckling. Fun puzzle, although I must say I found this easier than yesterday's, felt more like a Monday than a Tuesday puzzle.

Loved everything about this puzzle, especially the DIALUP clue and the Parks and Rec reference. Actually kind of a slow Tuesday time for me but had a blast anyway. I entered TEAMS for SKYPE and never questioned it until the end.
I know I keep my hammer in a tool room‚Äîsaid no one ever. Otherwise a nice puzzle.

Do some folks mispronounce ‚Äúempty‚Äù, somehow omitting the contribution of the ‚Äúp‚Äù, to arrive at something that sounds like ‚ÄúMT‚Äù? If so, how odd.

Didn‚Äôt care for the theme here. It would have been stronger had all the thematic entries been loaded with EMPTYCALORIES. Never heard of MAPOTOFU, but it‚Äôs hard to believe that it qualifies in that regard. Will have to research that one. Never heard of the MEATTORNADO either, but that one (like MOOSETRACKS and MINITWIX) seems likely to be nutritionally dubious.

Also seemed to be a lot of proper nouns in the grid.

Hope others enjoyed this one more than I did. Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd have accepted this one for publication.
Going to ask the gardeners out there instead of looking it up: are pansies really a kind of violet? Or vice versa? Got it from the crosses but it seemed odd.
I have a personal issue with TOOLROOM. Otherwise, a fun tuesday.

Terrific debut and a thoroughly delightful puzzle. There were a few things I didn‚Äôt know, MEAT TORNADO among them, but the crossings eventually brought it all together. And Sam was right about 44D being a hilarious clue. Perfect description of the sound of DIAL-UP. 

Congratulations, Henry Lin-David, and I hope we will be seeing more of you.

Congratulations to the author on this debut! I do want to say that as a therapist specializing in eating disorder treatment, I'm disappointed to see today's puzzle focus on diet culture concepts like "junk food" and "empty calories." Phrases like these are so commonplace that they may seem innocuous, but many people's eating disorders start from the belief that foods can be neatly judged as good or bad. I say this not to chastise the constructor--whose note suggests he has a happy and healthy view toward food--but instead just to put out there that no food that brings you joy is "junk" or "empty" of value.
Way above a Tuesday difficulty! They used to be nearly equivalent to Monday. This one is far from it.
@Dave S, that was three things for me...both I and a 6-year-old grandchild enjoy Moose Tracks ice cream
@Heidi  Onomatopoeia sure can make weird words...
@Ben Despite its reprehensible ownership, it did produce many excellent movies, whose directors, actors, etc., should not be tinged by association.

@Marshall Walthew 

What a great story. My mother used to make mapo tofu, but I never tried. Maybe you can share your recipe!

@Marshall Walthew

I love this story! I lived in Chester County and we‚Äôd often take regional rail to Ardmore for dinner rather than go all the way into the city. Beautiful place to live and eat!

@Marshall Walthew 

What a sweet story!  You just made wandering into a Tuesday thread worthwhile.

I'd never even heard of Ardmore and now you guys are making me want to visit and eat Chinese food there.  :)


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Marshall Walthew 
Are you talking about Hunan?  I had many wonderful meals there, although I think it closed at some point in the past couple of years, after having been in business for almost fifty years.

@Michael

It was indeed Hunan.  Sadly, the restaurant closed about a year ago, much to the dismay of its many loyal patrons.  Its doors had been open for almost 50 years.  When it opened in the mid 70s, it was a very brave venture, serving authentic Hunanese cuisine to a suburban populace that was weaned on chop suey and chow mein as exotic Chinese fare,  although I guess, because of Ardmore‚Äôs proximity to Philadelphia with its vibrant Chinatown, Ardmore was a little more prepared to be adventurous than some places might have been.  The owners, my friend Chris and his parents, are some of the finest people I know.
@Marshall Walthew I'm from Wynnewood! I know the restaurant! I also filled in MAPO TOFU from the clue without having any of the crosses

@Red Carpet 

Really the only thing that bothered me was the Wordplay column referencing dial-up and a "landline" in the same sentence.  When people relied on dial-up modems, the phone was just called.... the phone.  Obviously it became necessary to use "landline" to distinguish it only after cell phones became prevalent, and even then it took 10 or 20 years to move beyond geek lingo....  This was a little like seeing a similarity anachronistic reference to cave men riding dinosaurs.  :)

Cute Tuesday puzzle.  And the constructor's name seems built for crossword authorship.

I know it wasn't intended but I wonder whether some will object that mapo tofu isn't junk food.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Justin 

Thanks for that. I always enjoy Billy Collins‚Äôs poetry.

@Andrew I came here to acknowledge the same thing. It initially had me second-guessing myself, as if all the ‚ÄòUPs‚Äô were a mistake. 

Then it had me wondering if it was intentionally theme-adjacent, correlated to the ‚ÄòP‚Äô within ‚ÄòMPT‚Äô of EMPTY CALORIES‚Ä¶

Maybe that‚Äôs a stretch. 

Emus, while tall, can‚Äôt go too high up.

@Andrew 

Duplicates in grids don‚Äôt usually bother me, and I wasn‚Äôt conscious of those UPs while solving, but even by Will Shortz‚Äôs standards, that‚Äôs a bit ridiculous.

@Eric Hougland 

Really should be seven of them then....

Speaking of quality calories.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Eric Hougland 

If you weren‚Äôt conscious of them during the solve (and neither was I), what does it matter?

@Asher 

I was just as lost as you were, and had to rely on crosses to get those answers. It's not about getting old, but rather about the perils of having a trivia-based theme: if you don't know it you're gonna have a worse time than if you do.

@Asher 
Me too. Plus the pop music (I sound like my own Dad on the subject of the Beatles!)

@Andrzej 
Exactly. With me it is somewhat about age - I know a lot more about trivia from 60's to 80's when I listened to the music. Now I could solve Renaissance music ....

@Asher 

Moose Tracks is vanilla ice cream with fudge and peanut butter cup fragments or minis.

@Clare 

There is an a legendary story that at one time the football helmets for Middle Tennessee State University, had an MT on each side of the helmet.

@sotto voce 

I first heard of it at Serious Eats a bunch of years ago.  I don't think I've ever had it.  Despite the tofu, many/most versions aren't vegetarian.  :(

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Nancy J. 

Thanks Nancy!

Always looking for something good to put on noodles.  :)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Mike 
Cheezit!  The Cops!

@jma 

Mike always lays down the puns and ruffles feathers.  Wise to keep utz out of this, and close the door he tows.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Harry not just you. Took me longer than a normal Tuesday. Never had or heard of any of the EMPTY CALORIES 

I arrived at the MT soon enough which helped. 

Probably too easy for Wednesday. 

A late night Tuesday puzzle.

@Harry ,

Not just you.

@Harry 
A TOOLROOM is where Tool and Die Makers work. Many factories have them.
@Rallen better than Nevil Shute's novel?

@dutchiris 
Hah!  So that is TWO of us who mention that novel.  I didn't register the author's name (I read it in my teens, I think) but it's nice to know someone else found it memorable!

@Andrzej I needed lots of crosses for meat tornado, but was at least a little familiar with the others. And I love mapo tofu, and am surprised it's not on your radar. Is Chinese food uncommon in Poland? Perhaps you'll enjoy some when you visit New York

@Bob T. 

We have loads of Asian bars and restaurants in Poland, and Warsaw especially, but mostly Indian, Thai and Vietnamese ones. There are very few Chinese places though - I suppose it has to do with how many people from which country emigrate to Poland, and why. Many Indians, Thais and Vietnamese come to Poland specifically to found a small business, often a restaurant. Most of the Chinese I know come here for an education and then move on: I hear a lot of Chinese at my faculty, but almost none out in the streets and businesses.

Also, you have to remember migrations to Eastern Europe were severely limited before 1989, so all our immigrants are relatively recent arrivals. I suppose by that time the Chinese were not migrating as much as at the time many of them ended up in the US?

Most likely, you say EMP-tee when you're thinking about it, and EM-tee the rest of the time.  At the very least, your P undergoes reduction.  And if the word were "emty", you'd pronounce it exactly the same way, because the mouth wants to transition between the M and the T.

@Cyndie 

A lot of people around here misspell the name of the upstate city of Binghamton as Binghampton, following the pattern of Southampton and the other Hamptons on Long Island. That P wants to be there!

@Cyndie - there is a caesura or hiatus at the P of empty for many if not most English speakers; the P is an unreleased stop, indicated by the top half of this symbol ] following the letter P.
That is to say it is extremely rare to actually say ‚Äúemp‚Äôty‚Äù with an articulated P‚Äô; people either say /emti:/ or /emp.ti:/. Not a P, but a cessation of vibration on the M sound.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade

@KA Yellow is part of a streak (like, you did one yesterday and also today) and blue is not :)
@KA I think if it shows in blue, that it is not in fact, completed. There is at least one missing letter or there‚Äôs an error in the fill.
@KA Yellow means you solved it without checking or revealing any letters and you did it the day it came out so it counts towards your streak

@KA 

Are you talking about the stars, or the highlighted entries on the completed grid?

If you mean the stars, a gold star means you completed it without checking words or letters. The software is still not smart enough to know whether you looked things up offsite. Gold also means you did the puzzle when it was published, meaning that several in a row indicates a streak. A blue star just means you finished, either with checking, or from the archives. 

As for the highlighted answers in the completed grids, yellow indicates answers related to each other, such as when they constitute a theme,  the blue answer is just the last one you highlighted, with the one yellow square being the one you tapped/clicked on to do so. 

Hope this helps.

I said TOOLROOM several times today.  But I'm working on a special project.  Our church is in the process of turning the whole building into a massive museum-quality display of nativities scenes.  If you are in San Francisco Bay area, see www.christmascreche.org.  Free.  Dec 7-12.  Lots of family activities and concerts.

As we work on the setup, one of the church classrooms is called the TOOLROOM.  It is full of all kinds of tools and tape and lights and extension cords and ....
